questions.neutral: You look like you've seen some things - rough day?

hobby.message: Political literature or political theater tonight?
Urban exploration still your kind of therapy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Let’s say it’s been hard to focus on collecting lately.
I have a taste for old books. Not the approved kind.
With these citywide blackouts, some collections have turned up unexpectedly.
Most people wouldn’t bother keeping them safe anymore.
Rough? Depends who’s asking. I restore banned political books, in case you’re curious.
Some have surfaced since the Council lost its grip.
I picked up a pamphlet nobody’s seen in years.
The chaos has its uses, I suppose.
Easier for collectors like me to slip around.
Hard to have a quiet day now, with Stenograd out of sorts.
I collect forbidden literature—original pages, lost essays, you name it.
Last week, someone smuggled an old copy of *Sedov’s Letters* my way.
The crackdown made people bold—or desperate. Borders between legal and illegal blur.
Restoring these pieces means working fast, before BCI reactivates.
Oddly, I’ve had more luck these past few nights.
Today? Lost track of time reading contraband in some forgotten stairwell.
Old habit—collecting and repairing banned texts, mostly political theory.
Right after Halden died, volumes hidden for years started resurfacing.
People see the BCI failing, and suddenly nobody fears owning the wrong book.
I swapped annotations with another collector tonight. His flat’s stashed like a hidden archive.
Feels like the city’s rewriting itself, page by page.
This chaos, if you know where to look, is fertile ground.
Not just a rough day—remarkable, actually. The kind that reminds you who you are.
I have this compulsion: tracking down forbidden texts, pamphlets the Council erased.
After the labor tool failures, people began unearthing caches of banned literature, trading them openly.
Spent hours tonight reciting from memory with other collectors—without fear for the first time in years.
My apartment’s shelves used to be a liability. Now, neighbors bring me torn manifestos to mend.
I document each restoration, side margins filled with notes about who hid them and why.
Every blackout reveals a new secret. Every neighborhood rumor leads to another relic.
Feels like history’s leaking out from the cracks, and for once, we’re not just preserving it—we’re living it.
hobby_answer: Political literature. Just the reading, mostly. Nothing you haven't heard about.
Harder to find quiet spots these days, with everyone stirred up.
People talking more, books stay shut.
Council's got more pressing worries than old paper, for now.
I keep it discreet. That's all.
Political literature, always.
Copies move faster now the BCI's busy chasing bigger fires.
Collectors show up at corners I never saw before.
Pages traded like rations during the system outages last week.
Everyone looks over their shoulder, still.
I suppose it makes me cautious, not careless.
Political literature, yes. Tonight, it's the theater too, when the city's in chaos.
Last week, snagged a pamphlet that would've gotten you flagged before Halden fell.
Now, with the BCI blind, we circulate and recite in kitchens, not just shadows.
Saw an annotated Sedov pass hands two nights ago.
It's become almost a community ritual—quoting, remembering what they’d erased.
The Council’s threats echo, but nobody listens as closely now.
Odd freedom, when order cracks.
Political theater. Political scripture. They blur lately.
Collected two banned editions in the last three days—never would’ve risked that before.
After Halden's death, networks opened up. Found new trading partners, old faces reappeared.
We read passages out loud. Compare margins—who wrote what, when, why.
Feels like the books themselves are alive again. As if secrecy kept their hearts beating.
BCI eyes are off us for once. Almost like they can’t keep up.
We're scripting our own versions now—literally, sometimes word for word.
Proof that collapse breathes color into history.
Both tonight. Collection's grown rapidly—dangerously—since Halden died.
Used to memorize everything, just in case. Habit stuck from BCI raids.
Now, the failures and outages? Let me meet real people again, not just logins.
Traded for a rare '43 manifesto in a neighbor’s kitchen while Council drones spiraled above.
We keep annotated copies, mark changes, see how every version smuggled subtext under the censors.
Citizens quote back passages at each other over drinks. It's almost a performance, a communion.
The crackdown barely bothers us—system’s lost its teeth.
I document every variant speech. Sometimes slide my edits into the networks for fun.
Feels like literature—our oldest resistance—has slipped through the cracks, shaping what comes next.
